coredata.dc:title: Template-free, facile synthesis of nickel promoted multi-walled MoS2 & nano-bricks containing hierarchical MoS2 nanotubes from the bulk NiMo oxide
coredata.dc:creator: Chowdari, Ramesh Kumar
Díaz de León, Jorge Noé
Fuentes-Moyado, Sergio
coredata.dc:description: A low-temperature and template-free synthesis method was developed to prepare MoS2 nanotubes by sulfidation of bulk NiMo oxide. The ex-situ gas-phase low-pressure sulfidation of NiMo oxide resulted in multi-walled MoS2 nanotubes and NixSy spheres. Meanwhile, the in-situ liquid phase high-pressure sulfidation led to nanotubes formation by self-assembly of MoS2 nano-bricks vertically oriented towards the outer surface as observed by HRTEM analysis. The sulfided catalysts were evaluated for the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of dibenzothiophene (DBT) in a batch reactor. Catalyst sulfided under ex-situ conditions exhibited good performance (76 % DBT conversion with an initial reaction rate 24 × 10−8 molDBT.(gCat.s)-1). The in-situ sulfided catalyst showed an outstanding activity (99 % DBT conversion with an initial reaction rate 105 × 10−8 molDBT.(gCat.s)-1). Which means that the in-situ sulfidation method dramatically increased the initial reaction rate by four times. A mathematical expression (RKC equation) was derived to correlate the size of the regular hexagonal MoS2 nanoparticles with its activity, for which the experimental results were validated.

head.ce:title: Template-free, facile synthesis of nickel promoted multi-walled MoS2 & nano-bricks containing hierarchical MoS2 nanotubes from the bulk NiMo oxide

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Centro de Nanociencias y Nanotecnología, Km. 107 Carretera Tijuana-Ensenada, Ensenada, Baja California, 22860, Mexico
ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Centro de Nanociencias y Nanotecnología, Km. 107 Carretera Tijuana-Ensenada, Ensenada, Baja California, México-22860

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A low-temperature and template-free synthesis method was developed to prepare MoS2 nanotubes by sulfidation of bulk NiMo oxide. The ex-situ gas-phase low-pressure sulfidation of NiMo oxide resulted in multi-walled MoS2 nanotubes and NixSy spheres. Meanwhile, the in-situ liquid phase high-pressure sulfidation led to nanotubes formation by self-assembly of MoS2 nano-bricks vertically oriented towards the outer surface as observed by HRTEM analysis. The sulfided catalysts were evaluated for the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of dibenzothiophene (DBT) in a batch reactor. Catalyst sulfided under ex-situ conditions exhibited good performance (76 % DBT conversion with an initial reaction rate 24 × 10−8 molDBT.(gCat.s)-1). The in-situ sulfided catalyst showed an outstanding activity (99 % DBT conversion with an initial reaction rate 105 × 10−8 molDBT.(gCat.s)-1). Which means that the in-situ sulfidation method dramatically increased the initial reaction rate by four times. A mathematical expression (RKC equation) was derived to correlate the size of the regular hexagonal MoS2 nanoparticles with its activity, for which the experimental results were validated.

ce:section.ce:para: Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is a layered structure composed of a molybdenum layer sandwiched between two sulfur layers by weak van der Waals forces between Mo and S [1,2]. MoS2 has a wide range of applications in lubricants [3], hydrogen storage [4], hydrogen evolution reaction [5], transistors [6], lithium-ion batteries [7], hydrodesulfurization [8–10] and hydrodeoxygenation catalysis [11]. Several morphologies such as flower-like [12], fullerene shape [13,14], and nanotubes [15,16] are reported in the literature to enhance the performance of MoS2 in various technologies mentioned above [17]. Among the various morphologies of MoS2, one of the essential categories is the nanotube-like shape; it has great importance as it is analogous to the carbon nanotube with a lamellar structure [14,18]. The properties of MoS2 such as layered structure and the ultra-thin nanosheets flexibility make them into single-walled [19–22] and multi-walled MoS2 nanotubes [23–25] even at high hindrance.

Tenne et al. first reported the production of macroscopic quantities of fullerene-like MoS2 nanotubes by the gas-phase reaction between MoO3-x and H2S in a reducing atmosphere at elevated temperatures (800−950 °C) [18]. In the literature, most of the reported methods for synthesizing MoS2 nanotubes are high temperature, CVD methods, and multi-step synthesis [24–26]. However, a few reports are available for facile synthesis of MoS2 nanotubes; for instance, Wang et al. synthesized MoS2 nanotubes by the 3D assembly of single-layer MoS2 nanosheets using the hydrothermal method [22]. Zhuo et al. synthesized MoS2 nanotubes containing hierarchical nanosheets using hybrid MoO3-EDTA nanowires as a template for the photoelectron-catalytic hydrogen generation by water splitting [27], where L-cysteine is used as a sulfur source and EDTA as a template. In another report, iodine played a pivotal role in synthesizing multi-walled MoS2 nanotubes by chemical vapor deposition [23]. The authors reported that during the synthesis of nanotube bundles, iodine presence resulted in multi-walled nanotubes due to the thermal decomposition of amorphous Mo-S-I intermediate phase (outward diffusion of the iodine at high temperatures). On the other hand, the sphere particles are only observed in the absence of iodine. Interestingly, instead of the direct synthesis of MoS2 nanotubes, the MoS2 nanosheets are grown/anchored on carbon nanotubes [5,28] and graphene [29], where carbon material acts as a template and enhances the mechanical strength of the hierarchical MoS2 nanotubes.

As discussed above, expensive precursors, multi-step and high-temperature processes are employed to synthesize MoS2 nanotubes. However, limited reports are available on the application of MoS2 nanotubes for the HDS process [16,17]. Furthermore, large-scale production of MoS2 nanotubes is in the early stage. According to environmental legislation, the sulfur content in transportation fuels has to be < 10 ppm to reduce SOx emissions [30,31]. However, the production of ultra-low sulfur fuels (ULSF) from the sour crude oil distillates is a challenging task using supported Co/Ni promoted Mo/W-based catalysts [11,30,32]. In this context, the self-supported catalysts exhibited high activity (2–3 fold) than the conventional supported catalysts. Therefore, the fullerene-like hollow structured MoS2 materials could further enhance the HDS activity to produce ULSF as they possess low density and a large number of active sites [33]. Hence, the hollow structured MoS2 materials promoted by Ni could be used as a self-supported catalyst or one of the catalyst beds together with the supported one in the HDS/HDT reactors when aiming ULSF from the distillates containing high sulfur content (>2 %).

In the industrial HDS catalysis, the oxide catalyst is activated under in-situ conditions using spiked sulfur streams at high temperatures and pressures [34]. The advantages of the in-situ sulfidation method over the ex-situ method are, avoiding the exposure of the activated catalyst to the environment (attack of oxygen), ease of handling, and transportation of oxide material rather than the hazardous sulfided materials. Therefore, the loading of sulfided catalysts could result in low HDS activity and require a different activation processes to improve the HDS performance [35]. Also, the HDS activity is directly proportional to the active sites present on the edge of the hexagonal MoS2 crystal [32,36]. Therefore, vertically standing MoS2 nanosheets forming nanotubes, i.e., hierarchical MoS2 nanotubes [22], are highly desirable for the effective removal of the sulfur from the refractive molecules like DBT and its derivatives. Indeed, the experimental and computational studies on MoS2 crystal showed that extended MoS2 slabs are more stable than small ones. Therefore, during the oxide catalyst activation, MoS2 layers tend to agglomerate/merge, form large crystals, which decrease the number of active sites and loss of 2D ultrathin structures [37]. However, the aggregation of the MoS2 can be controlled and stabilized by interaction with support [38]. In the self-supported catalysts, control of the MoS2 slab size is of paramount importance to improve the HDS activity. Therefore, developing an oxide catalyst that could derive in hollow type MoS2 materials (hollow sphere or nanotubes) during the in-situ sulfidation (typical refinery protocol) is challenging.

In this context, in our previous work, Dandelion flower-like core-shell microspheres of NiYMo metal oxide were synthesized by a hydrothermal method and activated without a general particle morphology change [12]. In the reported synthesis procedure, we used a phosphorous precursor to generate heteropolyoxometalates to increase the hollow micro-spheres thermal stability [39,40]. In the current work, to study the molybdenum precursor effect, instead of isopolyoxometalate (IPOM), a Keggin type heteropolyoxometalate (HPOM) was used for the synthesis of the bimetallic NiMo oxide catalyst. The HPOMs and IPOMs differ evidently in chemical properties like thermal stability, acidity, and others [41,42]. The synthesized oxide catalyst was sulfided under atmospheric ex-situ gas-phase and high-pressure in-situ liquid phase conditions. The oxide and sulfided catalysts were thoroughly characterized by Fourier transform infrared attenuated total reflection (FTIR-ATR), nitrogen physisorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy-energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDS), and transmission electron microscopy-energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (TEM-EDS) techniques. The activated catalysts were evaluated for the hydrodesulfurization of DBT in a batch reactor. The HDS activity results were correlated with a theoretically derived model equation inspired by the partition of hexagonal MoS2 slab.

Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)3.6H2O), phosphomolybdic acid (PMA: H3PMo12O48.xH2O), hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA), dimethyldisulfide (DMDS), DBT, and n-hexadecane of reagent grade were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Infra Mexico supplied various gases like hydrogen (99 %), nitrogen (99 %), 15 % H2S/H2 gases.

The bimetallic self-supported catalyst was synthesized by hydrothermal method as follows: In a beaker, 1.9 g of PMA was dissolved in 25 mL of deionized (DI) water. To this aqueous solution, 1.75 g HMTA in 20 mL DI water was added dropwise while continuous stirring. The mixture was allowed to stir for 30 min. During the agitation of the mixture, a white precipitate was obtained due to the PMA decomposition into its constituent oxides (see Figure S1). An aqueous nickel nitrate solution (2.96 g in 30 mL of DI water) was added dropwise and allowed to stir for 30 min to the above mixture. The resultant final mixture was transferred into a 100 mL autoclave and heated to 150 °C for 24 h. After cooling the autoclave to room temperature naturally, the obtained green solid product was filtered using a Buckner funnel and washed with DI water. The obtained solid product was dried at 100 °C for 12 h and finally calcined at 300 °C at a ramp of 5 °C min−1 for 4 h. The obtained oxide sample was labeled as NiMo-PMA (indicates that NiMo catalyst was derived from phosphomolybdic acid).

Catalytic activity tests were performed in a 350 mL batch reactor (Parr) equipped with in- and outlet lines for the gases and collection of the reaction mixture during the reaction. Two different protocols were followed for the sulfidation of the oxide sample, viz. i) Ex-situ atmospheric gas phase sulfidation using 15 % H2S/H2 gas, and ii) In-situ high-pressure liquid phase sulfidation using DMDS and 50 bar H2 at RT.

In the atmospheric pressure catalyst sulfidation, 0.2 g of the oxide sample was taken in a ‘U’ shape quartz reactor. The reactor was heated at a rate of 5 °C.min−1 to the desired sulfidation temperature 350 °C and held for 2 h in a flow of 15% H2S/H2. Then the reactor was cooled to RT in the same gas flow and sulfided catalyst (denoted as mwnt-MoS2/Ni, where 'mwnt' indicates the multi-walled nanotube) was transferred to the 350 mL batch reactor containing 0.226 g DBT and 100 mL hexadecane (model diesel, ∼500 ppm of sulfur) under argon atmosphere. Then the reactor was flushed with nitrogen to evacuate the air and pressurized to 60 psi and the reactor was heated 320 °C at a ramp of 10 °C.min-1 while stirring the reaction mixture at 700 rpm. After stabilization of the reactor at desired temperature, approx. 0.5 mL of the reaction mixture was collected and considered as 0 h sample. Afterward, the reactor was depressurized to expel the nitrogen and hydrogen gas was introduced to desired pressure, 55 bar. The reaction mixture was collected at various interval of time up to 5 h. During the sample collection a minor decrease in the reactor pressure was compensated by introducing hydrogen gas to maintain constant pressure throughout the reaction.

To simulate the petroleum reinfiery sulfidation protocol, the high-pressure sulfidation was carried out in the liquid phase using dimethyldisulfide (DMDS) and hydrogen. For the in-situ sulfidation of metal oxides, DMDS was used as a sulfiding agent due to its high sulfur content [43–45]. During the catalyst sulfidation, the DMDS molecule readily decomposes and produces H2S. Initially, the batch reactor (350 mL) was loaded with 0.2 g of NiMo-PMA sample, 1 mL DMDS, and 100 mL n-hexadecane. Subsequently, the reactor was flushed with hydrogen and pressurized to 50 bar. The reactor was heated to 340 °C with a ramp of 10 °C min−1 while stirring at 700 rpm. During the heating, the reactor pressure auto-increased and reached 90 bar at 340 °C. The sulfidation procedure was continued for 2 h. Then, the reactor was cooled to room temperature and depressurized. About 0.226 g of DBT was added to the reactor. Afterward, the reaction was performed at 320 °C, as discussed before. The reaction samples collected were analyzed by Agilent gas chromatogram (FID) equipped with a DB-5 column and flame ionization detector. The FTIR-ATR spectra of the oxide catalyst and precusors were recorded on an Alpha II series Brucker Bio- spectrometer.
Raman spectra of the precursor and oxide catalyst were analyzed using a Horiba Xplora system interfaced with an Olympus BX41 optical microscope with a laser source of 532 nm.

Nitrogen physisorption analysis was performed to determine the surface area, pore-volume, and pore size distribution of oxide and sulfide catalysts using the conventional BET and BJH methods on a Micromeritics Tristar II instrument. The samples were degassed at 573 K under vacuum. Afterward, the N2 adsorption measurements were carried out at 73 K.

The XRD patterns of the samples were recorded on a Phillips X'Pert diffractometer in the 2θ range of 10−80° with a step of 1° (2θ) min−1 (CuK radiation 1.5406 Å). The catalyst MoS2 particle size was calculated using the Scherrer formula (Eq. 7).

The SEM images were recorded on a JEOL microscope model JSM-S300 and HR-TEM micrographs were recorded on a JEOL-JEM-2010 F microscope.

The surface chemical composition of the sulfided catalyst was analyzed using SPECS® X-ray photoelectron spectrometer, which consists of i) PHOIBOS® 150 WAL hemispherical energy analyzer (angular resolution < 0.5°) ii) XR 50 Al-X-ray, and iii) μ-FOCUS 500 monochromatic X-ray source (Al excitation line). Energy positions of the various elements were calibrated using the C1s binding energy (284.8 eV). The sulfided material was handled in a glove box under Ar atmosphere to avoid exposure to the environment. The deconvolution of the X-ray photoelectron spectra was done using a Gaussian-Lorentzian model curve fitting. Various chemical states of the elements present in the sample and the peak area percentages were taken into account for the quantitative analysis.

FTIR-ATR spectra of the phosphomolybdic acid along with HMTA and NiMo-PMA catalyst is shown in Figure S2. The characteristic peaks of Keggion ion at 1055, 955, 879, and 743 cm−1 corresponding to P–O (asymmetric stretching), M=Ot (asymmetric stretching), Mo-O-Mo (inter octahedral stretching), and Mo-O-Mo (intra-octahedral bridges), respectively, were identified [46]. The peak related to the HMTA molecule [47] and characteristic peaks of the Keggin ion of phosphomolybdic acid were absent in the NiMo-PMA catalyst indicating the complete decomposition of the HMTA molecule, and PMA in the synthesized NiMo-PMA catalyst.

The decomposition of Keggin PMA was further confirmed by Raman spectroscopy (see Figure S3). The peak at 1009 cm−1 is the characteristic peak related to the symmetric stretching mode of Mo=Ot in the Keggin type heteropolymolybdate [46,48]. Other intense bands at 851 cm−1 and 780 cm−1 are the bending mode of Mo-O-Mo of the corner and edge-sharing oxygen atoms in the heteropoly anion.

In the NiMo-PMA catalyst, the peak at 1009 cm−1 disappeared, indicating the phosphomolybdate anion decomposition. A new intense peak was observed at 947 cm−1, corresponding to Mo-O stretching vibration in the octahedrally coordinated polymolybdate (Mo7O24 -6) [49]. The peaks at 870 and 836 cm−1 were ascribed to the stretching vibration of Mo=O tetrahedral molybdate ion ((NH4)2MoO4), which might be formed due to the Keggin ion decomposition. The band at 357 cm−1 is related to the bending mode of Mo=O in tetrahedrally coordinated molybdate (MoO4 2-) [49,50]. These results indicate the decomposition of phosphomolybdate due to the addition of HMTA during the synthesis of NiMo-PMA catalyst. The FTIR-ATR analysis results agree with the deterioration of phosphomolybdic acid Keggin ion structure (See Figure S1, S2).

The synthesized NiMo-PMA catalyst exhibited type-III isotherms [51] as shown in the Supplementary Information, Figure S4. Since the NiMo-PMA catalyst derived from the phosphomolybdic acid, therefore, displayed a low BET surface area, 14.1 m2g−1 (see Table 1 ). A wide range of pore size distribution was observed between 3−120 nm with an average pore diameter of 30.5 nm and 0.14 cm3g−1 of the pore volume. In general, heteropoly acids possess a low BET surface area (< 10 m2g−1). Since phosphomolybdic acid was used for the catalyst synthesis, the low BET surface area was obtained for NiMo-PMA. After the oxide sample sulfidation, the catalysts exhibited 4.7 and 7.9 m2g−1 of BET surface areas corresponding to mwnt-MoS2/Ni and hnt-MoS2/Ni, respectively.

The SEM images of the NiMo-PMA catalyst are shown in Fig. 1 . From the SEM images, it was observed that two types (large spheres and tiny microspheres) of sphere shape particles were present in the NiMo-PMA catalyst (Fig. 1(a)). In the magnified images, it was noticed that the surface of the large spheres (Fig. 1(b)) consists of needle-like structures. This observation indicates that the bulky microsphere formed due to the self-assembly of a large number of nanorod/needle-like structures in such a way that one end of the nanorod pointing towards a center and the other end vertically orienting towards the surface resembling the Dandelion flower as shown in Fig. 1(d). On the other hand, the tiny micro-spheres possess a smooth homogeneous surface.

In our previously reported NiYMo catalyst synthesis, a similar Dandelion flower-like morphology was observed [12]. However, where the sphere-shaped hollow particle was formed due to many nanosheets self-assembly. In the current situation, the spheres were formed due to the self-assembly of the nanorods. For the preparation of both the catalysts (i.e., NiYMo and NiMo-PMA), HMTA was used as an organic base. However, the only difference is the use of isopoly- and heteropolyoxometalates; the HPOMs are more acidic than the corresponding IPOM. Also, HPOMs are less stable in the basic medium as the primary structure of the Keggin heteropoly-anion readily decomposes and produces its constituent metal oxides [52]. Therefore, a white precipitate was obtained for the HMTA and PMA mixture (See experimental section). By comparing both catalyst synthesis methods, it was noted that the use of IPOM (ammonium heptamolybdate) resulted in nanosheets formation, whereas HPOM (phosphomolybdic acid) resulted in the formation of nanorods. These observations showed that the type of Mo precursor has a significant effect on particle morphology.

The SEM-EDS spectrum of the NiMo-PMA catalyst is presented in the Supplementary Information as Figure S5. The EDS analysis confirmed the presence of Ni, Mo, O, and P. The weight percentage of the elements was as follows: 24.3 % (Ni), 35.3 % (Mo), 38.7 % (O), and 1.7 % (P) (see Table S1).

The NiMo-PMA oxide catalyst was characterized by TEM, and images are presented in Fig. 2 . The bulky Dandelion type microsphere primary unit, i.e., needle-like structures along with tiny microspheres, were observed in the TEM images (Fig. 2(a)). The crystalline lattice fringes of needle-like networks were observed in two directions, as shown in Fig. 2(b)&(c). Interplanar distance between the two layers was measured by the inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT) technique (see inset of Fig. 2(c)). The average distance between two crystalline planes was 0.326 nm, associated with the (0 2 1) plane of the α-MoO3 monoclinic phase [53]. The diffraction pattern is also presented in Fig. 2(d). These results indicated that the needle-like structured particles were exclusively consist of MoO3.

Fig. 3 shows the SEM images of the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. In Fig. 3(a), it was noticed that catalyst consists primarily of sphere shape particles. Likewise, the NiMo-PMA oxide sample, the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst also presented bulky sphere-like particles consisting of needle-like structures. This indicated the morphological stability in the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst even after the NiMo-PMA catalyst sulfidation. A similar type of flower-like system was reported for MoS2 nanotubes by Hoshyargar et al. [23] and Remskar et al. [54]. In Fig. 3(d), likewise, the NiMo-PMA catalyst the tiny spheres were also observed in the case of mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. However, there was a minor change observed for tiny spheres as it presented an uneven surface compared to NiMo-PMA catalyst particles. These observations indicated that the NiMo-PMA catalyst sulfidation resulted in a minor change of tiny microsphere, not in the bulky Dandelion type spheres.

In the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst, a similar observation was made as observed in the case of mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. Fig. 4 shows the SEM images of the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. The Dandelion type sphere remain observed in the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst (Fig. 4(b)). However, some of the spheres were partially broken and resulted in the formation of unhindered/free needle-like structures (Fig. 4(c)&(d)) that might be due to the high-pressure condition and mechanical stirring of the sulfidation feed. The SEM analysis of the sulfided catalysts confirmed the retention of the particle morphology in both cases.

The sulfided catalysts were further characterized by TEM to know the morphology and structural change after the NiMo-PMA sample sulfidation at high and low pressures. Fig. 5 shows the TEM images of the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. In the TEM images, two types of particles were observed, viz., sphere and needle-like structures, which were the primary units of bulky Dandelion type spheres (observed in SEM image, Fig. 3). In the SEM image (Fig. 3) of the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst, an irregular surface was noticed for the tiny spheres that could be seen in the TEM image as well (see Fig. 5(a)). In the HRTEM images (Fig. 5(b–d)), the open-ended nanotubes seen by several crystalline fringes of MoS2 located at either side forming multiple walls hence the catalyst was denoted as mwnt-MoS2/Ni nanotubes. In Fig. 5(d), few MoS2 slabs towards the inner wall and inside the nanotube were observed, indicating the participation of ultrathin MoS2 sheets in multi-wall nanotube formation during the sulfidation of NiMo-PMA oxide. Therefore, from the MoS2 slabs, length and stacking number were calculated, and the distribution chart is presented in Figure S6. The MoS2 slab length distribution was in the range of 5−17 nm with a stacking range of 2-11. The average slab length of MoS2 in the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst is 10.3 nm, with an average stacking number of 6 and with a d-spacing of 0.64 nm.

In Fig. 5(f), it was observed that spherical particles coated with multilayered, curved MoS2 slabs that appear like fullerene-type MoS2 [55]. Hence, the sphere surface seemed to be roughened, as observed in the SEM images (see Fig. 3(d)). The curved MoS2 resulted in a lowered d-spacing value (0.61 nm), which might be due to the contraction of the MoS2 layers compared to that obtained from the multi-walled nanotubes. A schematic representation of the multi-walled MoS2 nanotube and Ni spheres coated with multi-layer MoS2 is shown in Fig. 5(e).

The elemental mapping of the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst is presented in Fig. 6 . In the electron image (Fig. 6(a)) on the surface of the nanotube, a particle of around 10 nm was observed. The EDS chemical analysis indicated that it consists mainly of nickel and sulfur. In the case of the nanotubes it consists of Mo and S elements since no Ni was observed. Phosphorous, was also observed in the EDS image since phosphomolybdic acid was used during the synthesis procedure. These results were further confirmed by a line scan of the nanotube (shown in Supplementary Information, Figure S7). The relative intensities of the elements in the scanned region are shown in Figure S7(f). As seen only high-intensity peaks related to Mo, S and traces of Ni and P were observed.

Interesting results were obtained when the NiMo-PMA sample was sulfided at high pressure (hnt-MoS2/Ni). Fig. 7 shows the TEM images of the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. The TEM images (Fig. 7(a)&(b)) presented similar micrographs as those observed for the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst in terms of the sphere and needle-like primary units. However, the high-resolution TEM images of the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst exhibited quite distinct structures than the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. As the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst retained the nanotubular morphology; however, the nanotubes surface consists of a large number of nanometric MoS2 slabs which are vertically standing over the nanotube surface (termed as MoS2 nano-brick, see Fig. 7(c)&(d)). The tubular morphology in hnt-MoS2 appeared as self-assembly of MoS2-nano bricks as presented in Fig. 7(e). Such types of hierarchical structures are reported by Wang et al. [22]; however, the synthesis method involves the use of octylamine and ethanol as solvent. In Fig. 7(f), HRTEM images of the nickel sulfide micro microsphere particle surface are presented. Unlike the long, and curved fullerene-type MoS2 [13,15], observed for the mwnt-MoS2/Ni, the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst exhibited abundant nano-size MoS2 crystals (see the schematic representation in Fig. 7(e)). These results indicated that liquid high-pressure sulfidation resulted in the formation of small MoS2 slabs. On the other hand, atmospheric gas-phase sulfidation resulted in mw-MoS2 nanotubes (larger MoS2 crystals). Therefore, in the sulfide catalysts (mwnt-MoS2/Ni and hnt-MoS2/Ni), the surfaces of the spheres were not as smooth as observed in the NiMo-PMA catalyst.

The average length of the MoS2 slabs in the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst was far less than observed in mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. The distribution plots of MoS2 slab length and stacking number are presented in Figure S8. The MoS2 slabs size were in the range of 2−10 nm with a stacking number in the range of 2-7. From the stacking number distribution, it was observed that 85 % of MoS2 crystals consist of 3–5 layers, and 76 % of the MoS2 crystals were in the range of 4−7 nm in length. The average slab length of MoS2 was 5.7 nm, with an average stacking number of 4.

Furthermore, comparing the average external diameter of the MoS2 nanotubes (70.2 nm) in hnt-MoS2/Ni with the average diameter (69.3 nm) of nanorods in NiMo-PMA catalyst, is possible to infer an intraparticle rearrangement of the crystal structure due to the sulfidation process within the boundaries of the nanorod. In the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst, the average diameter of the MoS2 nanotubes was 58.8 nm. The decrease in nanotube diameter might be due to the contraction and sintering of the MoS2 slabs during gas phase sulfidation. The line scan EDS analysis of the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst also confirmed that nanotubes exclusively consist of Mo and S elements (Figure S9). However, the high pressure sulfidation resulted in an increase of Ni nanoparticles population on the MoS2 nanotube surface compared to mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst.

The X-ray diffraction patterns of the NiMo-PMA and sulfided catalysts (mwnt-MoS2/Ni and hnt-MoS2/Ni) are presented in Fig. 8 . The NiMo-PMA catalyst showed diffraction peaks corresponding to the hydrated α-nickelmolybdate (JCPDS no. 13-0128) [56]. However, in the TEM analysis of the oxide sample (NiMo-PMA) it is kown that the needle-like structures were exclusively consists of α-MoO3. From the sulfided catalysts TEM analysis, it is known that the nickel microsphere surface was coated with MoS2 layers. Therefore, in the oxide state (NiMo-PMA) the nickel microspheres surface covered with a molybdenum layer that might be forming the hydrated α-nickelmolybdate phase. Hence, the predominant peaks of α-nickelmolybdate originating from the nickel microsphere surface might suppress the needle-like MoO3 diffraction peaks in the XRD pattern. After sulfidation of NiMo-PMA sample under in-situ and ex-situ conditions, the prominent peaks originated at 2θ = 14.3, 33.2, 39.5, 50.8, 58.5, etc. ascribed to the (002), (100), (103), (105), (110) planes of hexagonal 2H-MoS2 phase (JCPDS No. 37-1492), respectively. The peaks related to various nickel sulfide species (NiS, NiS2, and Ni3S4) were also identified (see Fig. 8) in the XRD pattern. The mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst presented relatively sharp and intense MoS2 peaks than the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. The MoS2 crystal size also was calculated using the Scherrer equation (Table 1). The crystal sizes of the MoS2 particles were 11.6 and 4.5 nm for the mwnt-MoS2/Ni and hnt-MoS2/Ni, respectively. The particle size obtained from XRD analysis align with the TEM results (see Table 1). This observation further reiterates that small MoS2 crystals are present in the hnt-MoS2/Ni compared to the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst.

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy technique was used to identify the various species present in the sulfided catalysts [12,57–59]. Figure S10 shows the XPS of mwnt-MoS2/Ni in the emission regions of Ni, Mo, and S. The semi-quantitative yields of various species are presented in Table 2 . For the sake of clarity, only Ni 2p3/2 core emission line was deconvoluted (see Figure S10(a)). Three pairs of peaks (primary electron line emission and related satellite peak) were identified, NiS (852.8 eV), NiO (855.0 eV), and NiMoS (853.7 eV) phases with the semi-quantitative yields of 13.3 %, 24.1 %, and 62.6 %, respectively. A similar XPS profile was observed for the Ni 2p3/2 of the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst and presented in Fig. 9 (a). The high-pressure sulfidation protocol increased the NiS yield from 13.3%–28.4% with a simultaneous decrease in NiO percentage from 24.1%–10.9% in the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. These observations are in line with the results reported by Haandel et al. [36] as the degree of sulfidation is proportional to the sulfidation pressure. However, there was no significant change observed in the NiMoS phase quantification. This can be explained as follows, from the TEM (Figs. 5 and 7) analysis of the sulfided catalysts, it was known that most of the nickel sulfide particles were in the form of microspheres and coated with MoS2 slabs. Simultaneously, a large quantity of Mo was in the form of MoS2 nanotubes (exclusively contains Mo and S). Therefore, from the above observation, it can be concluded that the NiMoS phase was mainly originated from the surface of the nickel microsphere in both, mwnt-MoS2/Ni and hnt-MoS2/Ni catalysts. Since both sulfided catalysts (mwnt-MoS2/Ni and hnt-MoS2/Ni) were derived from the NiMo-PMA oxide sample. Therefore the quantified percentage of the NiMoS phase is almost similar in both catalysts. The atomic percentage of the various elements present in the sulfided catalysts was calculated from the high-resolution windows and presented in the Supplementary Information, Table S2. The calculated Ni/Mo atomic ratio for the mwnt-MoS2/Ni is 0.27 and 0.16 in the case of the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. The different Ni/Mo values for the mwnt-MoS2/Ni and hnt-MoS2/Ni catalysts might be due to rearrangement of the metal atoms (Ni and Mo) during the high-pressure and low-pressure sulfidation of NiMo-PMA oxide catalyst. The lower Ni/Mo ratio further confirmed that the nickel microspheres were covered with the MoS2 layers as observed in TEM images (Figs. 5 and 7).

Figure S10(b) shows the emission line region of the Mo 3d species, where the electrons of the S 2p core level also appeared. Three types of species were observed at binding energies of 229.0, 229.7, 232.6 eV, corresponding to the Mo4+, Mo5+, and Mo6+ oxidations states in MoS2, MoOxSy, MoO3, respectively [12,60]. Comparison of the quantification for the Mo species (MoS2 (72.3 %), MoOxSy (5.9 %), and MoO3 (21.8 %)) indicated that 72.3 % of molybdenum oxide was converted into active MoS2. On the other hand, hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst exhibited only two pairs of peaks related to Mo4+ and Mo6+ species with 91.9 % and 8.1 %, respectively (see Fig. 9(b)). The contribution of the Mo5+ species was not necessary to fit the spectrum. This indicates the absence of the oxysulfide species. The percentage of MoS2 in the low-pressure sulfided (mwnt-MoS2/Ni) and high-pressure sulfided catalysts (hnt-MoS2/Ni) is 72.3 % and 91.9 %, respectively. This further reiterates the significance of high-pressure sulfidation as the MoS2 percentage was about 27 % higher in the hnt-MoS2 than the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. In general, the formation NiMoS phase is proportional to the MoS2 content. However, the quantified NiMoS phase percentage was almost the same because catalysts mwnt-MoS2/Ni and hnt-MoS2/Ni, were derived from the NiMo-PMA. Comparison of both catalysts (mwnt-MoS2/Ni and hnt-MoS2/Ni) revealed that the degree of sulfidation is relatively high in the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst due to the high-pressure sulfidation protocol as reported by Haandel et al. [36].

The deconvolution of S 2p peak is presented in Figure S10(c). Two types of species were observed for sulfur (S−2 and S2 −2) in low and high-pressure sulfided catalysts associated with metal sulfides (see XRD pattern, Fig. 8). The percentage of yields of S−2 and S2 −2 species in mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalysts resulted in 88.4 % and 11.6 %, respectively. Whereas in the hnt-MoS2/Ni sample the quantification process showed 98.1 % of S−2 species, which is in agreement with the high yield of MoS2 for the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst (see Table 2 and Fig. 9(c)).

The hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene activity results over the sulfided catalysts is presented in Fig. 10 . The HDS of DBT reaction proceeds through the direct desulfurization (DDS) and hydrogenation (HYD) routes as shown in Scheme S1 (Supplementary Information). The products observed in the HDS of DBT are tetarahydro dibenzothiophene (THDBT), biphenyl (BP), cyclohexylbenzene (CHB), and bicyclohexyl (BCH). The product distribution as a function of DBT conversion over the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst is presented in Fig. 10(a). The variation in the product selectivity, HYD/DDS ratio as a function of DBT conversion (%) is presented in Fig. 10(b). From Fig. 10(a) it was observed that at the low conversion of DBT (5.1 %) only two products (BP and THDBT) were observed. The yield of BP and THDBT was 3.1 and 2 %, respectively. The high selectivity towards BP (62 %) indicated that the reaction was proceeded through the DDS route (at low DBTconversion). However, when the DBT conversion was reached 14.9 % formation of CHB was also observed; where the yield of CHB, BP, and THDBT were 2.9 %, 7.0, 5 %, respectively. In other words, the selectivity of the DDS route is 47.5 % and the HYD route is 52.5 % indicating that reaction proceeds through the HYD route (at 14.9 % DBT conversion). Up to 49.8 % DBT conversion there was no BCH observed. However, yields of CHB and BP gradually increasing with an increase in the DBT conversion. At 34 % of DBT conversion, yields of BCH and BP were almost similar (14.5 %). However, overall selectivity towards the HYD route was higher (57.2 %) due to the presence of THDBT (5.2 %). Beyond 50 % conversion of DBT, a drastic increase in the yield of hydrogenation product (CHB) was observed (42.5 % at an optimum conversion (76.1 %) of DBT). The yield of BP also increased however reached a maximum of 26.5 % when the DBT conversion was 76.1 %. From Fig. 10(b) it was observed that the selectivity of the DDS product decreased during the enhancement in the HYD product selectivity. Furthermore, an increase in the HYD/DDS selectivity ratio from 0.8 to 1.9 with an increase of DBT conversion from 2.8%–76.1 %, indicating that except at minor DBT conversion, the HDS of DBT mechanism over the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst was proceeded through the HYD route.

The HDS of DBT results over the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst is presented in Fig. 10(c) and the selectivity of HYD/DDS routes is presented in Fig. 10(d). At the low conversion of DBT, unlike the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst, the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst presented high selectivity (61 %) towards hydrogenation products even a low conversion of DBT (21.3 %) since the observed yields for CHB, BP, and THDBT were 8 %, 8.3 %, and 5 %, respectively. The formation of BCH was also observed when the DBT conversion attained 33 %, showing that the HDS reaction mechanism is following the HYD route. Comparison of the low-pressure and high-pressure sulfided catalysts showed that formation of BCH was observed only after 61.6 % DBT conversion over the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. The selectivities of CHB and BP products were similar at low DBT conversion (21.3 %). However, with an increase in DBT conversion from 21.3–89.2 % the yield of CHB was increased drastically from 8 % to 56.5 %. Similarly, the yield of BP was also increased however reached a maximum of 23.3 % only. At 94.8 % and above DBT conversion, BP yield was decreased with a simultaneous increase in the yields of CHB and BCH indicating the hydrogenation of BP. These results further confirmed that the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst is following the HYD mechanism in HDS of DBT. This was further confirmed from Fig. 10(d). The HYD/DDS ratio increased from 1.5–12.6, with an increase in the DBT conversion from 21.3–99%, indicating the strong hydrogenation ability of the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst.

The product selectivity, HYD/DDS ratio at isoconversion of DBT, initial reaction rate and rate constant, etc. are presented in Table 3 . The selectivity of the products compared at 34 and 33 % of DBT conversion over mwnt-MoS2/Ni and hnt-MoS2/Ni catalysts, respectively. A similar DBT conversion (33 %) was observed for the low-pressure sulfided catalyst only after 2 h for mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. Whereas in the case of high-pressure sulfided catalyst (hnt-MoS2/Ni) it was 0.5 h only. This is due to the presence of small MoS2 slabs in hnt-MoS2/Ni, as observed in the TEM analysis (see Fig. 7 and Figure S8). A narrow range (5−11 nm) MoS2 slab distribution was observed in the hnt-MoS2/Ni compared to mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst (a wide range between 5−17 nm). The average MoS2 slab length in the hnt-MoS2/Ni is 5.7 nm and is 1.8 times smaller (10.3 nm) than the MoS2 slabs present in the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. The selectivity towards the DDS product (BP) is 42.6 % for the mwnt-MoS2/Ni and 35.5 % in the case of the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. Similarly, the product selectivity in the HYD route is 57.4 % and 64.5 % for the mwnt-MoS2/Ni and hnt-MoS2/Ni catalysts, respectively. The HYD/DDS ratio is relatively low for the mwnt-MoS2/Ni (1.3) than the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst (1.8). These results indicated that both sulfided catalysts were following the HYD mechanism in the HDS of DBT. The hydrogenation effect is higher when the catalyst sulfided under high pressures. The initial reaction rate (contact time) significantly affects ultra-low sulfur fuel production in continuous reactors. For the sake of clarity the DBT conversion as a function of time is shown in Figure S11. The catalyst sulfided at atmospheric pressure (mwnt-MoS2/Ni) exhibited an initial reaction rate of 24 × 10−8 molDBT.(gcat.s)-1 which is relatively lower than the previously reported core-shell sphered NiYMo catalyst (42 × 10−8 molDBT.(gcat.s)-1) [12]. This is due to the presence of more extended MoS2 crystals in the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst (MoS2 slabs are in the form of nanotubes) compared to Dandelion-flower like morphology. Under a similar set of conditions, the hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst exhibited 105 × 10−8 molDBT.(gcat.s)-1 of initial reaction rate, which is four times higher than the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst. These results are indicating that the high-pressure sulfidation resulted in enhanced HDS activity owing to, i) high sulfidation degree (91.9 % of MoS2) than the low-pressure sulfided catalyst (72.3 % of MoS2) (Table 2) and ii) presence of relatively tiny MoS2 slabs (5.7 nm) in hnt-MoS2/Ni compared to the mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst (10.3 nm) (Fig. 7). Generally, it is known that the HDS activity of the catalyst is proportional to the percentage of the NiMoS phase in the catalyst. However, as discussed above the current catalytic systems exhibited a similar percentage of NiMoS phase not only contributing to the HDS activity but also the presence of mixed phases synergistic effect (MoS2 nanotubes/nickel sulfide microspheres).

From the comparison of the activity results of low and high-pressure sulfided catalysts it can be concluded that mwnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst could be used for the hydrodesulfurization process and hnt-MoS2/Ni catalyst in the hydrotreating process to enhance the diesel cetane number.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Derivation of the mathematical equation (RKC theory) for the relationship between the MoS2 slab size and HDS activity
ce:section.ce:para: One of the vital parameters to achieve high HDS activity is the crystal size of the MoS2. It has been reported that the activity of the HDS catalyst is related to the MoS2 crystal size [11,30–32 61,62] i.e., the smaller the MoS2 crystallite higher is the HDS activity since the activity of the catalyst is directly proportional to the edge sites of the MoS2 hexagon. To the best of our knowledge, no reports available on how the HDS activity vary with the MoS2 crystal size i.e., linear, exponential, among others. Therefore, an attempt is made to derive a mathematical equation between the MoS2 hexagon size and its HDS activity. Theoretically, it was proved that the regular hexagonal slabs are more stable than the irregular slabs [38,63] and except under controlled experimental conditions, the natural tendency of MoS2 slab shape is a regular hexagon. Therefore for the derivation of a mathematical equation, the regular hexagons were taken into consideration, and other factors such as crystal defects, curved MoS2, etc., were omitted.

Initially, MoS2hexagonal geometric model was considered as early reported by Kastelan et al. [64]. It is well-known that the number of active sites is mainly related to the perimeter (edges) of the MoS2 hexagonal slabs. From the data on the number of Mo atoms on edge and inside the MoS2 particles, it is possible to use the average slab length obtained from TEM, as Vrinat et al. [65] reported. These concepts were utilized to propose the current model; to simplify, a regular hexagon with a side (edge) length ( l1
) of 2 units was considered, as shown in Fig. 11 (a).

Therefore, the perimeter ( P1

Likewise, for the catalytic activity, it is reported that the increase in the MoS2 dispersion (i.e., as the size of the sulfide slabs decreases), the number of active (edge and corners) sites increases, and as a consequence, the HDS activity also increases [32]. Therefore, the activity of MoS2 hexagon is directly proportional to the density of the active sites, which in turn is directly proportional to the perimeter of the MoS2 hexagon. Hence, the total perimeter ( TPi
) of the MoS2 hexagon(s) is directly proportional to the HDS activity ( r ). Therefore the proposed parallel reasoning, the total activity ( ri

The final derived Eqs. (13) and (14) are called “RKC equations”.

For each case (regular and irregular hexagons), the validation of RKC Eqs. (13) and (14) is described in the Supplementary Information.

A novel and facile method is reported for the generation of multi-walled MoS2 and hierarchical MoS2 nanotubes from the bulk-NiMo catalysts derived from a heteropoly acid. A simple organic base, HMTA, was used for the precipitation of metal ions during the hydrothermal synthesis. Decomposition of the HMTA and PMA in the synthesized NiMo-PMA oxide was confirmed by FTIR-ATR and Raman spectroscopy. SEM and TEM analysis of the NiMo-PMA sample confirmed the Dandelion flower-like morphology containing the MoO3 nanorods self-assembly. In the sulfided catalysts, multi-walled MoS2 (for low-pressure sulfidation method) and hierarchical MoS2 nanotubes (for high-pressure sulfidation) made of nano bricks were observed. The formation of various sulfided species was identified by XRD and XPS analyses. The XPS analysis of the NiMo-PMA sample sulfided under high-pressure exhibited large quantities of MoS2 (91.9 %) compared to low-pressure sulfided catalyst (72.3 %). The sulfided catalysts HDS activity indicated that hnt-MoS2/Ni exhibited outstanding performance (105 × 10−8 molDBT.(gCat.s)-1) due to the tiny MoS2 nano bricks and high dispersion (low stacking number). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on the derivation of the mathematical expression (RKC equation) for the relation between the MoS2 crystal size and HDS activity. The experimental results are in agreement with the theoretically derived relation between MoS2 crystal size and HDS activity. The hierarchical MoS2 nanotubes are highly desirable for the production of ULSF since a simple and green synthesized method was employed for the production of the oxide catalyst. From the simple NiMo-PMA oxide (derived from heteropoly acid), either mwnt-MoS2/Ni and nht-MoS2/Ni catalyst can be generated simply by changing the sulfidation protocol. Based on the desired catalytic properties, these materials could also be used for other catalytic applications such as water splitting, bio-based fuels up-gradation, Li-ion batteries, etc.

SFM: Acquisition of funding, supervision, and review of the article.

Ramesh Kumar Chowdari: Original concept, design of the work, catalyst synthesis, measurement of catalytic activity, analysis-interpretation of the results, artwork, concept and derivation of the mathematical expression (RKC theory & equation) for the relation between the MoS2 crystal size and activity, original article writing, editing and review; Jorge Noé Díaz de León: XPS analysis, review of the article. Sergio Fuentes Moyado: Acquisition of funding, supervision, and review of the article.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Aligned MoOx/MoS2 core-shell nanotubular structures with a high density of reactive sites based on self-ordered anodic molybdenum oxide nanotubes
